title: Move file existence check to start of capture workflow
description:
Improve /capture workflow by checking for existing notes at the very beginning, before any user interaction.

## Current Behavior (User Experience)

User reports: The capture flow goes through the regular process (type detection, context questions, content generation) and only checks for existing files at the end before saving. This wastes time when the note already exists.

## Expected Behavior

Check if the file exists FIRST, before any other workflow steps:
1. Detect capture type
2. **Immediately check if note exists** (before any user questions)
3. If exists: Load the file, show existing content, ask what to update
4. If not exists: Continue with normal creation flow

## Current Implementation Analysis

**Documentation says check happens at:**
- URL captures: Step 1b (after type detection)
- Quick captures: Step 1d (after parsing, before context)

**But user experiences check at save time** - suggests agents may not be following documented workflow, or there's a secondary check at save time that's more visible.

## Root Cause Investigation Needed

1. Are agents actually performing the early check?
2. Is there a redundant late check at save time?
3. Is the early check failing silently and falling through?

## Conversation Context

This was discovered during a session exploring beads for AI-native issue tracking. User has been using /capture blip and noticed the inefficient workflow.
design:
## Files to Investigate/Modify

- plugins/jot/agents/capture.md - URL-based capture agent
- plugins/jot/agents/quick-capture.md - Quick capture agent
- plugins/jot/commands/capture.md - Command router

## Proposed Changes

### 1. Move Check to Absolute First Step

**For URL Captures (capture.md):**
```
Step 0: Check for Existing Note (NEW - before type detection)
  - Extract identifier from URL immediately
  - Check if file exists
  - If exists: Show AskUserQuestion with existing note preview
  - Only then continue to type detection if creating new

Current Step 1: Determine Content Type
Current Step 1b: Check for Existing Note  ← REMOVE/MERGE INTO STEP 0
...
```

**For Quick Captures (quick-capture.md):**
```
Step 0: Check for Existing Note (NEW - immediately after parse)
  - Parse input to get name/title
  - Check if file exists
  - If exists: Show existing note context, ask what to update
  - Only continue with session context gathering if creating new

Current Step 1d: Check for Existing Note  ← REMOVE/MERGE INTO STEP 0
...
```

### 2. Enhance the Existing Note Flow

When note exists, immediately:
1. Read the existing note content
2. Show key sections to user (summary, tags, etc.)
3. Ask: 'What would you like to add or update?'
4. Skip redundant questions (discovery context already in note)

### 3. Remove Any Duplicate Save-Time Checks

If there's a second check at save time, remove it or make it a silent overwrite.
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] File existence check happens BEFORE any AskUserQuestion calls
- [ ] For URL captures: Check happens immediately after URL is parsed
- [ ] For quick captures: Check happens immediately after name/title is extracted
- [ ] When file exists: Show existing note context before asking for updates
- [ ] No redundant 'file exists' prompts later in workflow
- [ ] Enhance flow skips questions already answered in existing note
- [ ] Original capture date preserved when enhancing
- [ ] Last Updated field updated correctly
close_reason: Implemented: Moved file existence check to Step 1 in both capture.md and quick-capture.md. Check now happens BEFORE any user interaction or context gathering.

title: Design README auto-generation strategy
description:
Analyze the current README.md structure to determine:
1. Which sections are static (philosophy, roadmap, contributing) vs dynamic (Available Plugins)
2. How to preserve manual customizations while auto-generating plugin sections
3. Whether to use marker comments (e.g., <!-- PLUGINS_START --> / <!-- PLUGINS_END -->) or full regeneration
4. Data sources: marketplace.json for plugin list, individual plugin READMEs for features

Deliverable: Document the chosen approach in the issue notes.
notes:
# README Auto-Generation Design

## Section Analysis

**Static Sections (preserve as-is):**
- Title & intro (lines 1-3)
- About section
- Philosophy section  
- Quick Start section (installation instructions)
- Roadmap section
- Contributing section
- License section

**Dynamic Section (auto-generate):**
- "Available Plugins" section (lines 43-201)

## Chosen Approach: Marker Comments

Use HTML comments to delimit the auto-generated section:

```markdown
## Available Plugins

<!-- PLUGINS_START -->
### devenv
...
### typst-notes
...
<!-- PLUGINS_END -->

## Roadmap
```

**Rationale:**
- Preserves all manual sections untouched
- Clear boundaries for generator
- HTML comments invisible in rendered markdown
- Easy to implement with simple text replacement
- Supports incremental adoption (can add markers to existing README)

## Data Sources

| Field | Source | Notes |
|-------|--------|-------|
| Plugin list | marketplace.json | Authoritative for which plugins exist |
| Description | marketplace.json | One-liner description |
| Features | plugin README.md | Parse "## Features" section, take first 5 bullets |
| Usage | plugin README.md | Parse "## Usage" or "### Command" section |
| Install | Template | `/plugin install {name}@claude-plugins` |
| Link | Template | `./plugins/{name}/README.md` |

## Plugin Section Template

```markdown
### {name}

{description}

**Features:**
{first 5 feature bullets from README}

**Install:**
\`\`\`
/plugin install {name}@claude-plugins
\`\`\`

**Usage:**
\`\`\`
{usage examples from README}
\`\`\`

[View documentation](./plugins/{name}/README.md)
```

## Sorting

Alphabetical by plugin name (simple, predictable, current approach)

## Implementation Notes

1. Generator reads marketplace.json for plugin list
2. For each plugin, parses its README.md to extract features/usage
3. Falls back to description-only if README parsing fails
4. Replaces content between markers (or appends markers if missing)
5. Integrated into /release after version bumps, before changelog

## Edge Cases

- **Missing README**: Use marketplace.json description only, skip features/usage
- **No Features section**: Generate from keywords/tags
- **No markers in README**: Add them around "## Available Plugins" content
- **Empty plugin list**: Keep markers with "No plugins available" message
close_reason: Design documented: marker comments approach with marketplace.json + plugin README parsing

title: Add jail.nix support to devenv plugin
description:
Add support for jail.nix (https://git.sr.ht/~alexdavid/jail.nix) to the /devenv plugin for sandboxed development environments.

## ⚠️ PLATFORM LIMITATION: Linux Only

**jail.nix uses bubblewrap which is Linux-only.** Bubblewrap relies on Linux kernel namespaces (user namespaces, mount namespaces, cgroups, seccomp) which do not exist on macOS.

macOS uses different sandboxing: sandbox-exec with Seatbelt profiles (App Sandbox). These are fundamentally incompatible approaches.

**Options:**
1. Implement Linux-only (document limitation clearly)
2. Future: Add macOS support via sandbox-exec (separate implementation)
3. Alternative: Use Anthropic's sandbox-runtime which supports both platforms

## What is jail.nix?

A Nix library that wraps derivations in bubblewrap for security sandboxing:
- Minimal permissions by default
- Combinators for permissions: network, gui, gpu, readonly, rw-bind
- Flake integration: inputs.jail-nix.url = "sourcehut:~alexdavid/jail.nix"
- Automatic path escaping for security

## Current devenv Plugin Architecture

- Location: plugins/devenv/
- Commands: commands/devenv.md (702 lines) - Initialize/manage flows
- Hooks: PostToolUse for nixfmt, statix, deadnix
- Config: .claude/devenv.local.md for user preferences

## Implementation Approach

1. Add jail.nix to security tools selection (alongside pre-commit, gitleaks)
2. **Detect platform and skip/warn on macOS**
3. Add sandbox policy options: strict, standard, permissive
4. Update flake template with jail.nix input
5. Wrap packages with jail combinators based on policy
6. Add management menu option for existing environments
design:
## Files to Modify

- plugins/devenv/commands/devenv.md - Add jail.nix to security tools flow
- plugins/devenv/README.md - Document sandboxing feature
- plugins/devenv/.claude-plugin/plugin.json - Add keywords

## Flake Template Changes

Add input:
```nix
inputs.jail.url = "sourcehut:~alexdavid/jail.nix";
```

Initialize in outputs:
```nix
jail = inputs.jail.lib.init pkgs;
```

Wrap packages:
```nix
packages = with pkgs; [
  (jail.wrap nodejs [ jail.network ])
  (jail.wrap python3 [ jail.network (jail.readonly "/etc") ])
];
```

## Configuration

Add to .claude/devenv.local.md:
```yaml
use_jail_sandbox: false
jail_policy: standard  # strict, standard, permissive
```

## Policy Presets

- strict: No network, no GUI, minimal filesystem
- standard: Network access, read-only common paths
- permissive: Network + GUI + GPU access
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] jail.nix appears in security tools selection during init (Linux only)
- [ ] Platform detection: Skip/warn jail.nix option on macOS
- [ ] User can choose sandbox policy (strict/standard/permissive)
- [ ] Generated flake.nix includes jail.nix input when selected
- [ ] Packages wrapped with appropriate combinators per policy
- [ ] Existing environments can add sandboxing via manage flow
- [ ] Configuration persisted in devenv.local.md
- [ ] nix flake check passes with jail.nix integration
- [ ] README documents jail.nix feature AND Linux-only limitation
notes:
## Platform Support

| Platform | Support | Reason |
|----------|---------|--------|
| Linux | ✅ Full | bubblewrap uses Linux namespaces |
| macOS | ❌ None | No kernel namespace support |
| WSL2 | ✅ Works | Linux kernel under the hood |

## Parked Reason

**No Linux environment available** - not interested in implementing until Linux system is available.

## Why bubblewrap doesn't work on macOS

Bubblewrap requires Linux kernel features:
- User namespaces (CONFIG_USER_NS)
- Mount namespaces
- PID/Network/IPC namespaces
- cgroups
- seccomp filtering

macOS lacks all of these.

## Potential Future Alternative

Anthropic's sandbox-runtime (https://github.com/anthropic-experimental/sandbox-runtime) supports both macOS (sandbox-exec) and Linux (bubblewrap).

## References

- bubblewrap: https://github.com/containers/bubblewrap
- jail.nix: https://git.sr.ht/~alexdavid/jail.nix

title: Add PNG export option to sketch plugin
description:
Add PNG export capability to the sketch-note plugin, which currently only generates Excalidraw JSON files.

## Current sketch-note Plugin

- Location: plugins/sketch-note/
- Output: sketches/*.excalidraw (JSON files only)
- Styles: hand-drawn (roughness 2), sketchy (1), clean (0)
- Templates: conversation, code-architecture, custom

## Available CLI Tools

### excalidraw-brute-export-cli (Recommended)
- Uses Playwright + headless Firefox
- Exact Excalidraw export fidelity
- Install: npm install -g excalidraw-brute-export-cli
- Usage: excalidraw-brute-export-cli -i file.excalidraw --format png -o file.png

### @tommywalkie/excalidraw-cli (Alternative)
- Uses node-canvas + Rough.js (no browser)
- Faster but may not match 100%
- Install: npm install -g @tommywalkie/excalidraw-cli
- Usage: excalidraw-cli file.excalidraw .

## Implementation Approach

1. Add --format flag: excalidraw|png|both
2. Add png_scale preference (1x, 2x, 4x)
3. Create export script that tries available CLI tools
4. Update generation workflow to export PNG when requested
design:
## Files to Modify/Create

- plugins/sketch-note/commands/sketch.md - Add --format option
- plugins/sketch-note/scripts/export-png.sh - New export script
- plugins/sketch-note/README.md - Document PNG export

## Command Changes

Add argument: --format excalidraw|png|both (default: excalidraw)

Add AskUserQuestion:
```
Output format:
○ Excalidraw only (.excalidraw) - Editable
○ PNG only (.png) - Shareable image  
○ Both formats (Recommended)
```

## Configuration

Add to .claude/sketch-note.local.md:
```yaml
output_format: excalidraw  # excalidraw, png, both
png_scale: 2  # 1, 2, 4
```

## Export Script (scripts/export-png.sh)

```bash
#!/bin/bash
INPUT="$1"
OUTPUT="${INPUT%.excalidraw}.png"
SCALE="${2:-2}"

if command -v excalidraw-brute-export-cli &> /dev/null; then
  excalidraw-brute-export-cli -i "$INPUT" --format png --scale "$SCALE" -o "$OUTPUT"
elif command -v excalidraw-cli &> /dev/null; then
  excalidraw-cli "$INPUT" "$(dirname "$OUTPUT")"
else
  echo "Install: npm i -g excalidraw-brute-export-cli"
  exit 1
fi
```

## Dependencies

- Node.js 18+
- excalidraw-brute-export-cli OR @tommywalkie/excalidraw-cli
- Playwright + Firefox (for brute-export)
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] /sketch --format png generates PNG file
- [ ] /sketch --format both generates .excalidraw and .png
- [ ] PNG scale configurable (1x, 2x, 4x)
- [ ] Graceful fallback when CLI tools not installed
- [ ] Clear installation instructions for dependencies
- [ ] Works with all templates (conversation, architecture, custom)
- [ ] Works with all styles (hand-drawn, sketchy, clean)
- [ ] README documents PNG export feature
